Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The purpose of this proposal is to request support for the PI to organize the 2016 NSF CPS PI Meeting. This meeting convenes all Principal Investigators of the National Science Foundation Cyber-Physical Systems Program for the fifth time since the program began. The PI Meeting is to take place on October 31- Nov 1, 2016 in Crystal City, Arlington, Virginia. The PI meeting is an annual opportunity for NSF-sponsored CPS researchers, industry representatives, and Federal agencies' representatives to gather and review new CPS developments, identify new and emerging applications, and to discuss technology gaps and barriers. The program agenda is community-drive and includes presentations (oral and poster) from PI's, reports of past year program activities, and showcase/pitch new CPS innovations and results.

The annual PI Meeting serves as the only opportunity where the CPS researcher community gathers to share their research, discuss new research opportunities and challenges, and explore new ideas and partnerships for future work. Furthermore, the PI meeting is also an opportunity for the academic research community to interact with industry entities and government agencies with vested interest in CPS research and development. The PI Meeting is a forum for sharing ideas across the CPS community. It has played a major role in growing the community across broad range of sectors and technologies, and performing outreach to others who have interest in learning about the program and participating as future proposers, transition partners, or future sponsors. The 2016 PI meeting will feature additional demonstrations to show the impact of CPS research. Finally, we expect to conduct discussions across the community with on considerations and ideas to inspire CPS 2.0.

POR.DRECONTENT:
2016 CPS PI Meeting – Project Outcomes Report

The 2016 Cyber-Physical Systems (CPS) Principal Investigators’ (PI) Meeting marked a significant milestone in the U.S. CPS program’s history – the 10-year anniversary of the CPS Program. The 2016 CPS PI Meeting was held on Monday, October 31 and Tuesday, November 1, 2016 at the Renaissance Arlington Capital View (RACV) Hotel located in the Crystal City Community of Arlington, Virginia at 2800 South Potomac Avenue, Arlington, Virginia 22202.

This seventh annual two-day gathering of over 400 stakeholders comprising CPS researchers, Government program directors, industry representatives, non-profit organizations, FFRDCs, and others, came together to discuss new and ongoing programs in CPS research being pursued by U.S. government research sponsor agencies. Over 270 PIs actively participated by presenting talks about accomplishments and challenges in their CPS research that span a diversity of technologies and application domains; identifying new, emerging problems, developments, and opportunities for research; showcasing their research results and accomplishments via posters, demonstrations, and videos; and interacting and networking to forge new collaborations with colleagues in academia, industry, and Federal agencies program managers, and other research organizations.

The program of the meeting included a day-one keynote by Charlie Catlett (Argonne National Laboratory & Argonne/University of Chicago Computations Institute’s Urban Center for Computation and Data) on the topic of the “Array of Things” (AoT). AoT is an urban sensing project comprising a network of interactive, modular sensor boxes, the first phase of which, has been installed in around Chicago to collect real-time data on the city’s environment, infrastructure, and activity for research and public use. Lily Yan (Intel) provided the day-two keynote that provided a status of the jointly funded Intel-NSF Center for CPS Security. Among other program discussions included talks about NSF’s effort to support research advances in Smart & Connected Communities. The progress of the CPS VO 2: Active Resources as well as the progress of the CPS student competitions using the VO were discussed.

Following is a breakout of the participation metrics and artifacts collected:

1. Actual Attendance Metrics:

  • Total number of actual attendees - 404
  • Total number of CPS Lead PIs, PIs, and Co-PIs attendees - 271
  • Total number of Government attendees - 40
  • Total number of industry attendees - 6
  • Total number of student attendees - 50
  • Total number of non-PI academics and Others - 24
  • Total number of project staff - 6
  • Total number of international attendees - 5
  • Others – 2

 

2. Registration Metrics:

  • 443 total number of registrants (based on pre-meeting data collected), including:
  • Total number of CPS Lead PIs, PIs, and Co-PIs attendees - 291
  • Non-PI academics - 30
  • Government representatives - 50
  • Industry representatives - 7
  • International representatives - 5
  • Students - 54
  • Others (NSF-Retired, AIT) - 2

 

Artifacts Metrics: The following artifacts were generated from the listing of 348 unique research grant awards for this meeting: 

  • 41 keynotes, invited talks, and R&D project presentations were introduced representing a broad range of disciplines have been archived
  • 211 project abstracts were submitted by PIs
  • 211 project posters were presented at the programmed poster session and have been archived.
  • 64 project videos have been submitted
  • 37 unique demonstrations by respective PIs were presented "live" in real-time

 

All public artifacts, including speaker presentations, position papers, the meeting program, meeting participant lists, and meeting organizers, have been disseminated to communities of interest via websites for the 2016 CPS PI Meeting that can be found at https://cps-vo.org/group/CPS-pimtg16. All program committee working documents are stored on the program committee’s private working group website at http://cps-vo.org/group/pimtg16-pc. These websites are permanently archived on the CPS VO, a web portal, which is managed and operated by Vanderbilt University’s Institute for Software Integrated Systems with funding support from NSF.

Additionally a “live” webcast of all presentations can be found on the public website at http://www.tvworldwide.com/events/nsf/161031/.

 

 

 

  

 


Last Modified: 09/30/2019
Modified by: Frankie King
